verse: These are the people of the ·area [province] who ·returned [were returning/on their way back] from ·captivity [exile], whom Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon had ·taken [carried] away to Babylon [2 Kin. 25:11–12]. They returned to Jerusalem and Judah, each going back to his own town.
These people returned with Zerubbabel [3:2], Jeshua [3:2], Nehemiah, Seraiah, Reelaiah, Mordecai, Bilshan, Mispar, Bigvai, Rehum, and Baanah.
the ·descendants [sons; and so throughout the list] of Parosh—2,172;
the descendants of Pahath-Moab (through the ·family [line] of Jeshua and Joab)—2,812;
the descendants of Ater (through the ·family [line] of Hezekiah)—98;
These are the people from the towns: of Bethlehem—123;
of Kiriath Jearim, Kephirah, and Beeroth—743;
of the other town of Elam—1,254;
These are the priests: the ·descendants [sons; and so on throughout the list] of Jedaiah (through the ·family [line; house] of Jeshua)—973;
These are the Levites: the descendants of Jeshua and Kadmiel (through the ·family [line] of Hodaviah)—74.
These are the ·singers [musicians]: the descendants of Asaph—128.
These are the gatekeepers of the ·Temple [house]: the descendants of Shallum, Ater, Talmon, Akkub, Hatita, and Shobai—139.
These are the Temple servants: the ·descendants [sons; and so throughout the list] of Ziha, Hasupha, Tabbaoth,
These are the descendants of the servants of Solomon: the descendants of Sotai, Hassophereth, Peruda,
The Temple servants and the descendants of the servants of Solomon numbered 392.

·Some [The following; Another group of] people came to Jerusalem from the towns of Tel Melah, Tel Harsha, Kerub, Addon, and Immer, but they could not prove that their ·ancestors [families; house of their fathers and their seed] came from Israel.
They were the descendants of Delaiah, Tobiah, and Nekoda—652.
Also these priests: the descendants of Hobaiah, Hakkoz, and Barzillai, who had ·married a daughter [taken a wife from the daughters] of Barzillai from Gilead and was called by her family name.
These people searched ·for their family [or in the genealogical] records but could not find them. So they could not be priests, because they were ·thought to be unclean [disqualified; desecrated].
The governor ordered them not to eat any of the ·food offered to God [sacred food; most holy things] until a priest ·had settled this matter by using [stood up with] the Urim and Thummim [Ex. 28:30].
The total number of ·those who returned [the company/assembly/group] was 42,360.
This is not counting their 7,337 male and female servants and the 200 male and female singers they had with them.

When they arrived at the ·Temple [house] of the Lord in Jerusalem, some of the ·leaders of families [heads of the fathers] ·gave [made voluntary] offerings to rebuild the ·Temple [house] of God on the same site as before.

They gave as much as they could to the treasury ·to rebuild the Temple [for this work]—·about 1,100 pounds [61,000 drachmas] of gold, ·about 6,000 pounds [5,000 minas] of silver, and 100 ·pieces of clothing for the priests [priestly garments/robes].
All the Israelites settled in their hometowns. The priests, Levites, ·singers [musicians], gatekeepers, and Temple servants, along with some of the other people, settled in their own towns as well.
